title: Hezbollah confirms the death of its top commander in Israel strike in Beirut that left 14 dead
summary: The strike marks the first time Israel has hit the Lebanese capital since July. Friday, the UN said that the detonation of hand-held communication devices in Lebanon could constitute a war crime.

title: Palestinians seeking asylum in France on the rise
summary: In the first eight months of 2024, some 190 residents of the Palestinian territories requested protection from France, compared with 67 in the year 2023.

title: 'She should be alive today:' Harris blasts abortion bans and Trump
summary: Vice President and Democratic candidate Kamala Harris has been outspoken on abortion rights ever since the Supreme Court's decision more than two years ago, but Friday's speech was her first focused squarely on the issue.

title: Long-awaited French government to be unveiled over the weekend
summary: President Emmanuel Macron and Prime Minister Michel Barnier are set to finalize a new cabinet before Sunday, signaling a shift to the right in key government positions.

title: At French mass rape trial, the silent shock of watching the first videos
summary: The court on Thursday, which is now examining the 49 co-defendants on trial for the rape of Gisèle Pelicot, had to resort to viewing chilling footage filmed by her former husband to decide a contentious case.

title: With 'No Name,' Jack White returns to his rock roots
summary: Secretly released this summer, the sixth solo album by the guitarist, singer and producer revives the White Stripes' galvanizing garage blues-punk.

title: The hidden trial of Navalny's three lawyers
summary: The attorneys of Putin's main opponent, who died in prison in February, are being tried for 'extremism' behind closed doors in a small, peaceful town.

title: With 'The Seed of the Sacred Fig,' Mohammad Rasoulof dives into the totalitarian horror of an Iranian household
summary: The filmmaker portrays the intimate workings of autocratic thinking through the prism of a middle-class family.

title: US Secret Service admits complacency that led to shooting during Trump rally in July
summary: The US House of Representatives unanimously passed a bill Friday to boost Secret Service protection for presidential candidates to the same level as sitting presidents and vice presidents.

title: AI start-ups are feeling the economic pressure
summary: Creators of artificial intelligence models and AI tools are facing skepticism about the existence of a 'bubble' in the sector and competition from digital giants.

title: Starmer couple's fondness for gifts is causing controversy in the UK
summary: Accommodation expenses, clothing, tickets to Taylor Swift concerts and football matches: In five years, the Labour leader is said to have accepted gifts worth a record £100,000.

title: Lack of funding puts the preservation of France's historic monuments at risk
summary: Concentrating on just a few major projects, the French government is unable to cope with the huge investment required to maintain thousands of sites owned by small communities and individual owners. Private funding is struggling to pick up the slack.

title: Since the war, Syrian women gained in autonomy in a society still dominated by men
summary: 'Syrian Diaries' (6/7). After their husbands were killed, imprisoned or have fled abroad, many women find themselves alone at the helm of the household.

title: Spanish enclave of Ceuta under pressure from Moroccan migrants wishing to reach Europe
summary: Following Sunday's attempt, another mass border crossing is planned for September 30, organized on social media. These crossings now primarily involve Moroccan nationals, whereas until now they were mainly attempted by sub-Saharan migrants.

title: Late Harrods owner Al-Fayed accused of sexual assault by dozens of women
summary: Harrods had already begun settling claims with women in 2023 about sexual abuse by the Egyptian billionaire tycoon Mohammed Al-Fayed, who died last year.

title: In the Congo Basin, environmental NGOs step up efforts to include Indigenous populations
summary: Photographer Thomas Nicolon visited the Bayaka, who are now part of forest protection teams in the Congo Basin. Hunting was banned when a national park was created in Congo-Brazzaville, but many members of this indigenous group have found new jobs.

title: European Heritage Days: 10 ideas for seaside visits
summary: The culture section of Le Monde offers a selection of sites highlighting maritime heritage. The 41st edition of the event takes place on Saturday and Sunday.

title: Le Monde's festival celebrates the paper's 80th anniversary with debates, concerts and more
summary: Le Monde is celebrating its 80th anniversary (and the 10th anniversary of the Le Monde festival!) from September 19 to 22, 2024.

title: How will Michel Barnier play his environmental card?
summary: As environment minister in the 1990s, the current prime minister laid some of the foundations of France's environmental policy. A pioneer in his right-wing party regarding environmental issues, he then virtually stopped addressing them.

title: Georgia board passes rule change mandating hand count of ballots
summary: The ruling is sparking fears of delays and chaos in the November presidential vote. Also Friday, the Arizona Supreme Court ruled that nearly 98,000 people whose citizenship documents hadn't been confirmed can vote in state and local races.

title: The olive tree, maltreated symbol in occupied land
summary: Since 1967 and Israel's occupation of the West Bank, thousands of olive trees have been destroyed by Israeli authorities and settlers. Between 2022 and 2023, photographers Adam Broomberg and Rafael Gonzalez immortalized the trees left still standing, some of them thousands of years old − emblems of Palestinian roots in these territories.

title: Ukraine worries about the prospect of massive power cuts in the winter
summary: While Ukraine has continued to lose energy production capacity since the invasion began, power cuts could last between four to 18 hours a day, and even longer in the event of further Russian strikes on the country's infrastructure.

title: Japan orders evacuations in quake-hit region on flooding fears
summary: Tens of thousands of people have been told to evacuate in the region of Ishikawa as three rivers are overflowing.

title: Springfield, its cats and Haitian migrants reflect the deep polarization of the US
summary: This Ohio town has been the center of attention ever since Donald Trump, during his debate against Kamala Harris, peddled his running mate's false accusations against the Haitian community and local pets.

title: Videos will not be broadcast 'systematically' at French mass rape trial
summary: Roger Arata, president of the criminal court, has decided to determine on a case-by-case basis whether or not to broadcast these images, 'with the sole aim of establishing the truth,' and to impose a closed session when the videos are shown.
